title: If I were to travel back to the middle ages, would I be more at risk for disease and sickness than other people of that time period? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you are a substantially younger person than me then you probably don't have a vaccination against small pox. However smallpox epidedemics wasn't very common in most of that period. It occurred more towards the Renaissance, as trade-routes became more direct. Black death is caused by a Gram negative bacillus called Yersina Pestis. No known vaccine exist against Gram-negative bacilli. Typhus and typhoid fever would be endemic. Don't drink the water, even with a vaccination. Yellow fever vaccination would only be relevant if you go to Africa. (You didn’t say where you wanted to travel. Timbuctu and Zimbabwe , and Ethiopia would have been on my list of destinations in year 1200) There are so many diseases that we treat with antibiotics. Even when the cause is viral infection, the antibiotics kill germs that thrives on a weakened body. Which is why there has been an excessive use; it helped even if it wasn't strictly necessary. If you cannot bring some with you, then you might be in a worse condition than the locals. You might also be in a better condition as you probably have a healthy body. It’s a gamble, just like any travel to places with more primitive health care.

Your biggest asset is your knowledge. On your plus side, you have had vaccinations against some of the nastier stuff (if you’re old enough you might even be immune against smallpox) and you haven’t been subject to starvation, so you’ve got a better “baseline health”. On your minus side, you’re not the survivor of several epidemics and haven’t worked hard with your body all your life, so you’ve got a worse “acquired health”. But you know how diseases spread. You know that a wound can be disinfected by some distilled alcohol, you know that if you boil water it is safe, you know that a well next to a cesspit is a bad idea. You know about hygiene and that epidemics spreads between people, not through “bad air” or “humours”. If you’d been cut with a knife and the wound got infected, a medieval doctor would generally focus any treatment on the knife. The only thing they did to you was to let blood, which wouldn’t help. Don’t let on what you know. They’ll call it witchcraft and it’s the stake for you. Say it’s some sort of trick you learned from an Arab doctor you took prisoner during a crusade, or something, and make sure to wave a crucifix at whatever you’re doing. They’re viciously superstitious.
